edge: The film won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 2007, which is considered one of the highest honors in the film industry.
The film grossed $171 million worldwide against a budget of $25 million, making it a commercial success.
The film premiered in competition at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival on May 19.
Joel Coen, alongside his brother Ethan, directed the film.
Javier Bardem's portrayal of Anton Chigurh in the film received widespread critical acclaim and won several awards.

Moss plans to give Carla Jean the money and hide her from danger at a motel in El Paso.
Carla Jean's mother unknowingly reveals Moss' location to the group of Mexicans tailing them.
Bell arrives at the motel in El Paso only to find that the Mexicans have killed Moss.
Bell returns to the crime scene and observes the lock blown out. Bell thinks that Chigurh is hiding, but when Bell hesitantly enters, he finds the room empty.

Later, Bell visits his cousin Ellis and tells him he plans to retire because he feels overmatched by the recent violence. Bell learns from Ellis of a story in which a lawman, Ellis' uncle, was killed on his porch and says that the region has always been violent. Carla Jean returns from her mother's funeral to find Chigurh waiting in the bedroom. Bell's encounter with Chigurh leads to Carla Jean facing Chigurh.
Chigurh says he must fulfill his vow, but offers a coin toss as a compromise. Carla Jean refuses to call it, saying that he will be responsible for her fate.

Now retired, Bell shares two dreams with his wife. In the first, he lost some money his father had given him. In the other, as he rode through a snowy mountain pass, his father rode past him to prepare a campfire ahead.
Bell shares two dreams with his wife, and Chigurh appears in neither dream.

Rudin bought the film rights to McCarthy's novel.
The Coen brothers agreed to write and direct an adaptation of McCarthy's novel, after being suggested by Rudin.

node_1: james dickey's novel 'to the white sea'
edge: At the time, the Coen brothers were attempting to adapt James Dickey's novel 'To the White Sea', but eventually chose to adapt McCarthy's novel instead.
The Coen brothers were attracted to how the book provided an unconventional approach, which was familiar and congenial to them.
The Coen brothers liked how McCarthy did not follow through on formula expectations, which was a hallmark of the book.
The Coen brothers identified with how McCarthy provided a sense of place and also played with genre conventions, which allowed them to find some kind of beauty without being sentimental.
The Coen brothers explained that the pitiless quality was a hallmark of the book, which had an unforgiving landscape and characters.
The Coen brothers also explained that the bad guys never really met the good guys in McCarthy's novel, which was a departure from formula expectations.
The Coen brothers' adaptation of McCarthy's novel was the second of McCarthy's work, following All the Pretty Horses in 2000.
The Coens' script was mostly faithful to the source material.
One of us types into the computer while the other holds the spine of the book open flat.

As explained by Kelly Macdonald, "the ending of the book is different. She reacts more in the way I react. She kind of falls apart. In the film she’s been through so much and she can’t lose any more. It’s just she’s got this quiet acceptance of it"
Some attention is paid to the daughter, Deborah, whom the Bells lost and who haunts the protagonist in his thoughts.
Miller's Crossing was a sly, unacknowledged blend of two Dashiell Hammett tales, Red Harvest and The Glass Key;
But No Country for Old Men is their first film taken, pretty straightforwardly, from a prime American novel.

Richard Corliss of Time stated that "the Coen brothers have adapted literary works before. Miller’s Crossing was a sly, unacknowledged blend of two Dashiell Hammett tales, Red Harvest and The Glass Key; and O Brother Where Art Thou? transferred the Odyssey to the American south in the 1930s. But No Country for Old Men is their first film taken, pretty straightforwardly, from a prime American novel."
They pruned where necessary.
A teenage runaway who appeared late in the book and some backstory related to Bell were both removed.

Josh Brolin discussed his initial nervousness with having so little dialogue to work with, stating 'I mean it was a fear, for sure,' because as an actor, dialogue is what he typically relies upon. He continued, 'Drama and all the stuff is all dialogue motivated. You have to figure out different ways to convey ideas. You don't want to overcompensate because the fear is that you're going to be boring if nothing's going on.' Peter Travers of Rolling Stone praised the novel adaptation, stating, 'Not since Robert Altman merged with the short stories of Raymond Carver in Short Cuts have filmmakers and author fused with such devastating impact as the Coens and McCarthy. Good and evil are tackled with a rigorous fix on the complexity involved.'

node_2: balance and harmony in society's religious, aesthetic, and practical life
edge: Yeats's ideal rarely realized in this world and maybe not even in ancient Byzantium. The historical period of Byzantium was a time of culmination that was also a time of transition. In his book of mystical writings, A Vision, Yeats says, "I think that in early Byzantium, maybe never before or since in recorded history, religious, aesthetic, and practical life were one, that architect and artificers ... Spoke to the multitude and the few alike." This ideal is contrasted with the sense of things being out of alignment and harmony gone from the land and people in the context of the movie No Country for Old Men, as explained by Craig Kennedy.

edge: Craig Kennedy points out that "one key difference is that of focus. The novel belongs to Sheriff Bell. Each chapter begins with Bell's narration, which dovetails and counterpoints the action of the main story. Though the film opens with Bell speaking, much of what he says in the book"

Relates the Yeats poem to the Coens' film, saying: "The lament that can be heard in these lines is for no longer belonging to the country of the young. It is also a lament for the way the young neglect the wisdom of the past and, presumably, of the old..."

The famous coin-tossing scene between Chigurh and the old gas station clerk is a good example; the camera tracks in so slowly that the audience isn't even aware of the move. "When the camera itself moves forward, the audience is moving, too. You're actually getting closer to somebody or something. It has, to me, a much more powerful effect, because it's a three-dimensional move. A zoom is more like a focusing of attention. You're just standing in the same place and concentrating on one smaller element in the frame. Emotionally, that's a very different effect."

node_2: everything's storyboarded before we start shooting
edge: "Everything's storyboarded before we start shooting," Deakins said in Entertainment Weekly. "In No Country, there's maybe only a dozen shots that are not in the final film. It's that order of planning. And we only shot 250,000 feet, whereas most productions of that size might shoot 700,000 or a million feet of film. It's quite precise, the way they approach everything."

The Coen brothers weave together the figures of Chigurh and the sheriff at the beginning of the film, as the sheriff's voice accompanies the images of Chigurh's arrest. This initial connection is further developed when the sheriff visits Llewelyn Moss' trailer home in search for Moss and his wife, Carla Jean, as Chigurh had visited only minutes before and sat down in the same exact spot where Chigurh had been sitting. The Coen brothers have the sheriff sit down in this spot. The sheriff sees himself reflected in the dark glass of Moss' television, their mirror images perfectly overlapping if one were to superimpose these two shots. This mirroring goes beyond the level of reflection as Chigurh enters into the sheriff's constitution, thus further undermining any easy opposition of Chigurh and the sheriff, and instead exposing a certain affinity, intimacy, or similarity even between both.

node_2: importance of violence to the story
edge: Joel Coen acknowledged that 'there's a lot of violence in the book,' and considered the violence depicted in the film as 'very important to the story.' He further added that 'we couldn't conceive it, sort of soft pedaling that in the movie, and really doing a thing resembling the book ... it's about a character confronting a very arbitrary violent brutal world, and you have to see that.'

Los Angeles Times critic Kenneth Turan commented on the violence depicted in the film: 'The Coen brothers dropped the mask. They've put violence on screen before, lots of it, but not like this. Not anything like this. No Country for Old Men doesn't celebrate or smile at violence; it despairs of it.'

Gillmore describes No Country for Old Men as a mixing of the western and film noir genres, reflecting the two sides of the American psyche: perseverance and skill lead to triumph in the western genre, while smarts and wits face overwhelming odds and eventual failure in film noir. By combining these genres, the Coens create a western with a tragic, existential, film noir ending.

The tension between destiny and self-determination is a theme in the story. According to Richard Gillmore, the main characters are torn between a sense of inevitability and the notion that our futures are connected to our past actions.
